ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Well, it's the only course on prehistoric invertebrates (and their modern analogues), so.
Greater understanding of basic paleontological practices; broad-strokes understanding of marine invertebrate taxonomy and evolutionary history; greater understanding of geology research practices.

This course was an overview of major invertebrate groups but was not intended to be phylogenetic in scope. We learned how to interpret fossils and the basic biology and evolutionary history of key groups. Functional morphology was emphasized.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some groups were completely left out (e.g. insects) and I wish we could've looked at ecology and how these different groups may have interacted with other organisms or with their environments, or in general if we could've looked at these by time period versus by group. But I'm really glad this course does exist, especially because the only assignment is a research project (+ presentation), which both takes stress away from studying and allows the student to explore their interests scientifically.
Prof. Briggs was very knowledgable and helpful, very willing to support us when needed. However, the lectures could get very dry and disengaging, which made it hard to focus.

The teaching is strong and the lectures are always very interesting and engaging. The ability to interact with specimens every class was special. The project was a good opportunity but a real commitment, and some people would maybe want to audit the course without having to go through an entire project, although I found it rewarding.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Anyone who's interested in paleontology, biology, invertebrates, or the history of life should take this course! And it gives you good hands-on experience with a research project (whether it's a lit review or an actual experiment).

If you're super interested in marine invertebrates and/or paleontology, take it to get a greater understanding of form/function relationships and paleontological practices. But, if you're just looking for a science credit or an elective but don't have a strong interest in the above fields, maybe don't, since it can get kind of dry. Prof. Briggs is super knowledgable and supportive, but it can still dry. There's also only one assignment the whole semesteran independent lab research projectso if you don't have strong experience with this kind of work, it can be overwhelming.
